Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Subrahmanya Krishnamoorthy is "Shimura Curves in Positive Characteristic." The host institution for the fellowship is the Free University in Berlin, Germany, and the sponsoring scientist is Helene Esnault.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a result of the fellowship, I embarked on three collaborations, based in England, Germany, and China. Loosely, all of the projects are based on the following question: which ordinary differential equations come from algebraic geometry? Surprisingly, many conjectured answers of this question use modulo p arithmetic. Thanks to the NSF award, I have (at least) seven joint papers (including works still in progress) investigating this question. These projects are in a loose sense an outgrowth of my PhD thesis; however, my time at FU Berlin certainly helped develop and refine these ideas. This was largely because my group, led by Helene Esnault, thought about very related questions in arithmetic geometry; in fact, I learned several of the key techniques in the aforementioned articles from our research seminar at FU.

 

As I described in the original broader impacts, submitted in October 2015, one of my goals was to further create links between European and US mathematicians. In this respect, I feel I have succeeded; I have been invited back many times to visit universities in Germany, France, England, and Hungary. I have also linked several young American colleagues with European colleagues in related areas. Finally, as a result of a collaboration during my NSF fellowship, I co-organized a workshop in London last summer  that included mathematicians from the US and Europe.
